Award.AwardTitle: EAGER - GLOBE (NSF16-031): Collaborative Research: Leveraging GLOBE student and citizen science data on the Flyover Country mobile platform for place-based, data-driven education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on developing the capacity to expose and visualize GLOBE data collected by citizen scientists and students in the geoscience mobile app Flyover Country (FC). This application for mobile devices displays Earth data and geologic maps drawn from public databases, and caches this information on the mobile device for offline use. The user can then access a wealth of curated geoscience content while in flight, on a road trip, or on a hike. In addition to presenting GLOBE data alongside with other data, the project will develop associated visualization and interactivity functions for FC. These functions include a "mission" or "call to action" for the user to collect GLOBE observations if his or her driving FC path intersects a region that is underrepresented with respect to GLOBE data; a time slider to visualize changes in data point values over time (i.e., the past 20 years of GLOBE data collection); and an application programming interface to improve access to GLOBE data. These functions will be of great utility not only to the GLOBE user cases, but also to all users of FC and potential users/analysts of GLOBE data. GLOBE data in FC will also benefit from novel cartographic visualization strategies being developed.

It is expected that GLOBE data will accessible to the 100,000 users of FC. In addition, there is the possibility of developing new exercises for use in classrooms where computers may be limited, but access to mobile devices may be more within reach. The investigators will assess the use of FC-with-GLOBE in the classes at a community college, and use the same assessments with other groups, including diverse undergraduate students conducting research, Native American students in K-12 science camps, and students in attending universities and field camps. The results will be shared in one or more publications. The promotion of the GLOBE Program to the academic research community, through the incipient development of FC as a research application, will raise awareness of the program as a highly desirable partner for developing meaningful broader impacts activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flyover Country is a map-based mobile app that enables users to access geological data and cultural landscape information. Through an easy-to-use, intuitive interface, users select map layers and personalize their map view to include the features and data that interest them. Designed for use in both formal and informal educational settings, as well as for use by individuals, Flyover Country promotes understanding of Earth system science through place-based exploration of landscape features and human cultural history through mobile access to scientific data while in the field. 

This project merges these existing innovative data access features of Flyover Country with attributes of the GLOBE Observer citizen science data collection app. GLOBE Observer is an international network of citizen scientists and scientists working together to learn more about our shared environment and changing climate. The GLOBE Observer mobile app, released in 2016, enables the systematic collection of environmental measurements and observations by citizen scientists.

We created three key enhancements to the Flyover Country App that serve to benefit and promote public Earth science education: (1) access to GLOBE Observer citizen science data layers through the Flyover Country map interface, (2) push notifications from scientists who seek citizen science data from a user's location, and (3) interoperability between the two apps, so that users of Flyover Country can navigate to GLOBE Observer while in app and respond to data calls created by scientists while in the field. 

GLOBE Observer citizen scientist data is now available to Flyover Country users as one of the interactive map layers. Visualization of GLOBE Observer citizen science data in the Flyover Country app serves to elevate the user's perception of the importance of citizen science and signals its critical contribution to the broader scientific enterprise. Flyover Country provides an exciting, inclusive window to Earth science that displays the research outcomes of citizen scientists alongside data layers derived from the work of professional scientists.

The second innovation created in this project was to promote and encourage the collection of citizen science data through push messaging to users of the Flyover Country app. The map-based interface employed in Flyover Country provides an important feature that is not available on GLOBE Observer. At any map location, users have access to geological data and cultural features that create a context for their citizen scientist observations. They can access data layers to ascertain what is known about their immediate location. In doing so, they can envision that no matter where they are, there is always still more to discover.

To leverage this awareness, we wanted to prompt new and potential citizen scientists to report data when using the Flyover Country app. We created a digital workflow that enables Earth system scientists to request users to collect and report data they need. A geofencing feature references a scientist's research area in a map polygon and contacts users who are near or within that polygon. A push message is sent notifying the user that they are in a place where a scientist has identified a need for citizen science data. For instance, a local ecologist might be studying vegetation succession after a fire, or a land cover specialist may need additional data to interpret an ambiguous feature identified in satellite data. A person who is using the Flyover Country app will be served with a specific ask notification, such as, "A scientist needs tree height measurements in your area. Can you help?" The app serves up a button where the user can navigate from the Flyover Country app, enter the GLOBE Observer app, and upload scientific observations. If the user does not have the GLOBE Observer app installed on their mobile device, they are directed to the app store where they can upload the free app.

In summary, this project provides (1) immediate access to scientific data and information using a user-friendly map-based interface, and (2) an impetus to contribute to our scientific knowledge of the Earth through personalized, place-based requests for citizen science data. Through the pairing of two popular mobile apps we expect that it will be possible to dramatically increase citizen science participation on the GLOBE Observer platform. To date, Flyover Country app has 300K downloads (as of December 2019); the GLOBE Observer app has 179K downloads (as of June 2020). Through creating Flyover Country- GLOBE Observer interoperability, we hope to engage a new population of passive science data consumers as active participants in our nation's scientific enterprise. Through promoting active engagement in place-based science discovery and encouraging active research by citizen scientists, the innovations in the Flyover Country app supports enhanced scientific literacy and broadens public awareness of the changes taking place in our Earth's system. 

Data products resulting from this project are open source and will be accessible through the Github Repository (https://github.com/FCGI) in Summer 2020.
